Parameters.Text:
Welcome back to MindTrails! Let's get started with practicing flexible thinking. 

Today, you will: answer a few questions about your anxiety, complete 3 scenarios that challenge you to come up with thoughts, feelings, and behaviors, and wrap-up with a Quick Thinking exercise. 

Let's get started!

Thinking about the last 24 hours, how anxious have you felt? 

0 = Most calm I could imagine being. 

10 = Most anxious, panicked, or scared I could imagine being.

Please touch the sliding bar to select your response, or press 'More options...'

Thinking about the last 24 hours, how much were you able to change the way you thought about things when you wanted to feel better. 

An example might be: If you were feeling worried about an upcoming test, were you able to remind yourself that you studied a lot and were prepared? 

0 = Not at all - I wasn't able to think in different ways to feel better. 

10 = Completely - I was totally able to think in different ways to feel better.

OtherChoices: I didn't want/need to change my feelings

Parameters.Text:
Thinking about the last 24 hours, how much did you try to stay away from or be less involved in situations that would make you anxious or scared? 

An example might be: If your teacher asked a question to the class and you knew the answer, do you not answer so you won't draw attention to yourself? 

0 = I tried to stay away from doing anything and everything that would make me anxious or scared. 

10 = If there was something that would make me anxious or scared, I pushed myself to do it anyway.

OtherChoices: Nothing happened that made me anxious

Parameters.Text: In this exercise, please think of an UPCOMING situation that you expect will make you feel anxious, worried, or scared. Pick a situation that you worry might go badly, or that you expect will bring on feelings of anxiety (like racing heart, sweating). Any situation that will make you feel quite anxious or scared will work, as long as it is a situation that is likely to actually happen.
Please describe the situation in a few words:

Please imagine the situation as vividly as possible (i.e., so that it feels very real). Try to imagine you are actually in the situation. Play out the specific parts of the situation in your head. Try to imagine using all your senses while you think about this situation. Think about the things you would see, hear, and smell if you were really in that situation. Think about the kinds of things you would think or feel if you were actually there.
Play this situation in your head for the next 20 seconds. The screen will change automatically after 20 seconds

How anxious did you feel (at the highest level of anxiety) as you completed the imagery task?  

0 = Absolutely no anxiety. 

10 = Totally anxious.
How vividly did you imagine the situation?
How likely is it that the situation or task will turn out well versus turn out badly?

Items: Very likely to turn out well
Somewhat likely to turn out well
Somewhat likely to turn out badly;Very likely to turn out badly

Parameters.Text: If this situation did turn out badly, how well or badly would you be able to handle it?

On the next screen, you will be asked to write about a possible upcoming event in your life, or something that you are worried might happen. Before pressing NEXT, please think about a situation that might happen over the next week when you will feel anxious, scared, or worried. This can be a situation that makes you anxious a lot, or something that doesn't happen a lot. 

As you think of an event, try to really see yourself in the situation. Where are you? What day of the week is it? What time is it? Who is around you? What are you doing? How do you feel?  

After you come up with your situation, please press NEXT.  

Examples could include taking a test, talking to strangers, using social media, dealing with family or friends, or whatever makes you feel anxious.
Please take a moment to write one or two sentences to describe the situation. Press next when you are ready to continue.
For the next 30 seconds, please picture yourself in this situation. When you are finished, the screen will change automatically.

Now, take the next 90 seconds to think of as many different thoughts that you could have in the situation as you can. These thoughts can be negative or positive. Be as creative as possible with all of the different thoughts you could have while you're in the situation that makes you anxious, especially thoughts that would help you feel less anxious.  

Please type each of the thoughts in the box below. You can put each thought on a new line. 

The screen will change after 90 seconds.

Great job! You predicted the future! Now, if your situation happens over the next week, you can have a lot of different thoughts come into your mind. Try to remember some of your thoughts that make you feel less anxious!
Great job practicing flexible thinking today. Remember, try to use your new flexible thinking skills before your next training session!

Sections.Name: Domains
Sections.Description: The domains listed here are some areas that may cause teens to feel anxious. Please select the one that you'd like to work on during today's training.

Parameters.Text:
Next, you're going to see a scenario that might make you anxious. As you read the short story, picture yourself in that situation. After you picture yourself in the situation, click "Next" and then you'll see examples of thoughts, feelings, and behaviors that might happen in that situation. 

Some of the thoughts, feelings, and behaviors will be helpful and some won't be.

The goal of this exercise is to help you learn that there are lots of different reactions that you might have in a scary situation, and not all of these thoughts, feelings, and behaviors have to be negative. 

After you see some thoughts, you'll be asked to write your own example of a helpful thought that you might have in that situation. You'll do the same thing for feelings and behaviors.
Picture yourself in the situation on the next page.
Your English teacher calls on you to answer a question about the book you just read. You say your best answer and your peers are quiet.

Your English teacher calls on you to answer a question about the book you just read. You say your best answer and your peers are quiet.

Here are some thoughts that might pop into mind:

Text: My answer was thoughtful.
It was nice to be able to share what I think about the book.
My classmates are judging my wrong answer.
My answer sounded dumb because I didn't understand the book, but no one will remember tomorrow.
If my English teacher didn't call on me, I wouldn't have made a fool of myself. I'll have a better answer next time.

Parameters.Text:
Now's your chance to be creative! What could you say to yourself to make you feel better in this situation?  

For the next 30 seconds, write as many different thoughts that you might have that would be helpful in this situation. You can use the thoughts that you saw a moment ago for inspiration, or can list things that you've told yourself in the past that have helped. 

What could you tell yourself in this situation that would help you feel less anxious or would help you handle your feelings of anxiety?

Press enter after each thought to write a new one on each line.

Your English teacher calls on you to answer a question about the book you just read. You say your best answer and your peers are quiet.

Thoughts in the moment:
Great job! Now you'll see some feelings.

Your English teacher calls on you to answer a question about the book you just read. You say your best answer and your peers are quiet.

Here are some feelings that might happen in the moment:

Text: I'm glad my teacher gave me the opportunity to share my answer.
I'm satisfied with how I said my answer.
I was scared while answering
I'm disappointed in myself because I couldn't say what I wanted to say, but I think my teacher understood my point.
I was really anxious while I was answering, but was able to manage my feelings.

Parameters.Text:
Now you try! What are some feelings that you could have in the moment? These don't have to only be feelings that you've had in the past or negative feelings that you assume you'd have in the moment. Think creatively about both positive and negative feelings that may come up for you in reaction to the situation. If you write a negative feeling, try to also write how you might cope with that feeling. 

Please take 30 seconds to write as many different feelings that you could imagine having in this situation. You can be as creative as you want. If you write any negative feelings (like scared or anxious), try to also write how you could help yourself feel better in the moment.

Press enter after each feeling to write a new one on each line.

Your English teacher calls on you to answer a question about the book you just read. You say your best answer and your peers are quiet.

Feelings in the moment and how you'd handle any negative feelings:
Great job! Now you'll see some behaviors.

Your English teacher calls on you to answer a question about the book you just read. You say your best answer and your peers are quiet.

Here are some behaviors that someone might do at that moment or in the future:

Text: I think about my answer, smile, and sit back.
I'll review my notes from this book before my test.
I won't answer again in class.
I feel like I should crack a joke so my friends forget about my answer, but don't.
I want to cry, but I take a moment to calm down and focus on the teacher's next question.

Parameters.Text:
Your English teacher calls on you to answer a question about the book you just read. You say your best answer and your peers are quiet.

Behaviors you might do in the moment:

Great job! You've completed the first of three training exercises. Next you'll do the same exercise with a new story. 

Again, the goal of this exercise is to help you learn that there are lots of different reactions that you might have in a scary situation, and not all of these thoughts, feelings, and behaviors have to be negative.
Picture yourself in the situation on the next page.
You have a science test next week that's going to count for a lot of your grade. You haven't understood this unit's course material that well and you wonder how the test is going to go.

You have a science test next week that's going to count for a lot of your grade. You haven't understood this unit's course material that well and you wonder how the test is going to go.

Here are some thoughts that might pop into mind:

Text: I'm a good student.
I'll do my best on my test next week.
My parents will be upset if I don't do well.
I'm dumb for not understanding this material, but I bet if I study really hard I can learn some of the material.
I'll fail this test, but that doesn't mean I'll fail the class.

Here are some feelings that might happen in the moment:

Text: I'm confident that I can study really hard for the test.
I feel good about how I've done well in the class so far.
I'm scared to take the test.
I'm embarrassed to ask for help, but that feeling will pass.
I'm nervous for my test next week, but I'll be able to handle it.

Feelings in the moment and how you'd handle any negative feelings:
Great job! Now you'll see some behaviors.

You have a science test next week that's going to count for a lot of your grade. You haven't understood this unit's course material that well and you wonder how the test is going to go.

Here are some behaviors that someone might do at that moment or in the future:

Text: I'll ask questions in class when I don't understand something this week.
I'll ask my teacher for help this week.
I'll avoid studying for the test when I feel anxious.
I want to avoid asking for help, but I reach out to my teacher anyway.
I really don't want to make flash cards, but I will anyway because I know it'll be helpful for the test.

Parameters.Text:
You have a science test next week that's going to count for a lot of your grade. You haven't understood this unit's course material that well and you wonder how the test is going to go.

Behaviors you might do in the moment:

Way to go! Now you just have one training exercise left. You're going to practice coming up with thoughts, feelings, and behaviors one more time, and this time the story is going to be from a different topic than the first two you just did. This is to help your brain practice this kind of thinking in lots of different types of situations.
Picture yourself in the situation on the next page.
You go to your grandparents' home for the first time in a while and notice that your grandfather looks a lot less healthy than you remember. No one in your family mentions it.

You go to your grandparents' home for the first time in a while and notice that your grandfather looks a lot less healthy than you remember. No one in your family mentions it. 

Here are some thoughts that might pop into mind:

Text: I wonder how my grandfather is feeling.
He's happy to see me.
My grandfather must be dying.
I think about how miserable I would be if he passes away, but then remind myself to enjoy my time with him today.
My family must be keeping a secret about his health, but then tell myself that everyone ages.

Parameters.Text:
Now's your chance to be creative! What could you say to yourself to make you feel better in this situation?  

For the next 30 seconds, write as many different thoughts that you might have that would be helpful in this situation. You can use the thoughts that you saw a moment ago for inspiration, or can list things that you've told yourself in the past that have helped. 

What could you tell yourself in this situation that would help you feel less anxious or would help you handle your feelings of anxiety?

Press enter after each thought to write a new one on each line.

You go to your grandparents' home for the first time in a while and notice that your grandfather looks a lot less healthy than you remember. No one in your family mentions it. 

Thoughts in the moment:
Great job! Now you'll see some feelings.

You go to your grandparents' home for the first time in a while and notice that your grandfather looks a lot less healthy than you remember. No one in your family mentions it. 

Here are some feelings that might happen in the moment:

Text: I feel happy to see my grandfather.
I feel excited to catch him up on all the new things that are going on in my life.
I'm worried about how he looks.
I'm scared to lose him, but know that I can handle grief.
I feel anxious about his health, but tolerate the anxiety.

You go to your grandparents' home for the first time in a while and notice that your grandfather looks a lot less healthy than you remember. No one in your family mentions it. 

Here are some behaviors that someone might do at that moment or in the future:

Text: I decide to give him a big hug and smile.
I make a funny joke to get my grandparents laughing.
I make a concerned face at my family.
I want to leave and cry, but decide to stay with the family and engage in conversation.
I gently ask my grandfather how he's doing and accept any answer he gives me.

Parameters.Text:
You go to your grandparents' home for the first time in a while and notice that your grandfather looks a lot less healthy than you remember. No one in your family mentions it. 

Behaviors you might do in the moment:

Next, you're going to see a scenario that might make you anxious. As you read the short story, picture yourself in that situation. After you picture yourself in the situation, click "Next" and then you'll see examples of thoughts, feelings, and behaviors that might happen in that situation. 

Some of the thoughts, feelings, and behaviors will be helpful and some won't be.

The goal of this exercise is to help you learn that there are lots of different reactions that you might have in a scary situation, and not all of these thoughts, feelings, and behaviors have to be negative. 

After you see some thoughts, you'll be asked to write your own example of a helpful thought that you might have in that situation. You'll do the same thing for feelings and behaviors.
Picture yourself in the situation on the next page.
You are sitting on the bus and see your friend get on. They walk past you and sit with another friend.

You are sitting on the bus and see your friend get on. They walk past you and sit with another friend.

Here are some thoughts that might pop into mind:

Text: I'm able to sit here alone for the rest of the ride.
My friend probably had something to talk about with the other friend.
My friend walked past me on purpose.
It feels like my friend is mad at me, but they would have said something.
I really don't like sitting alone, but I know I can handle this short bus ride.

Parameters.Text:
Now's your chance to be creative! What could you say to yourself to make you feel better in this situation?

Great job! Now you'll see some feelings.

You are sitting on the bus and see your friend get on. They walk past you and sit with another friend.

Here are some feelings that might happen in the moment:

Text: I'm excited to see my other friends at school today.
I'm glad that this is a short bus ride.
I'm annoyed with my friend right now.
I'm scared that people will judge me, but I can turn and talk to the people around me.
I am anxious about why my friend walked past me, but I can ask them about it later.

Parameters.Text:
Now you try! What are some feelings that you could have in the moment? These don't have to only be feelings that you've had in the past or negative feelings that you assume you'd have in the moment. You are sitting on the bus and see your friend get on. They walk past you and sit with another friend.

Here are some behaviors that someone might do at that moment or in the future:

Text: I call out to my friend and smile.
I turn to the seat behind me and start to make a joke.
I start to cry.
I'll want to ignore my friend the rest of the day, but I'll be nice since that's the right thing to do.
I want to put my head between my knees and disappear, but I take a deep breath and smile.

Parameters.Text:
You are sitting on the bus and see your friend get on. They walk past you and sit with another friend.

Behaviors you might do in the moment:

Great job! You've completed the first of three training exercises. Next you'll do the same exercise with a new story. 

Again, the goal of this exercise is to help you learn that there are lots of different reactions that you might have in a scary situation, and not all of these thoughts, feelings, and behaviors have to be negative.
Picture yourself in the situation on the next page.
You and your friends are shopping at the mall. You go to the food court and get slushies, and accidentally spill your red slushie down the front of your new white shirt.

You and your friends are shopping at the mall. You go to the food court and get slushies, and accidentally spill your red slushie down the front of your new white shirt.

Here are some thoughts that might pop into mind:

Text: I think about how this is a common accident.
I think about how it will be a funny story.
I think I will look silly in front of everyone.
I'm annoying to my friends right now, but they will understand that accidents happen.
I'm causing a scene, but the other people here don't know me or care about this situation.

Parameters.Text:
Now's your chance to be creative! What could you say to yourself to make you feel better in this situation?

You and your friends are shopping at the mall. You go to the food court and get slushies, and accidentally spill your red slushie down the front of your new white shirt.

Here are some feelings that might happen in the moment:

Text: I'm feeling silly and decide to chuckle about it.
I'm glad that this is an old shirt.
I feel embarrassed and it's making me want to leave the mall.
I'm so annoyed with myself, but am able to get past this feeling.
I'm self-conscious with this stain, but no one else will care.

Parameters.Text:

You and your friends are shopping at the mall. You go to the food court and get slushies, and accidentally spill your red slushie down the front of your new white shirt.

Here are some behaviors that someone might do at that moment or in the future:

Text: I wipe up the slushie, smile, and keep shopping with my friends.
I laugh and buy another slushie.
I'll cry and leave the mall.
I want to leave immediately, but know that I'll forget about the stain soon.
I want to throw away the slushie, but decide to keep eating it.

Next, you're going to see a scenario that might make you anxious. As you read the short story, picture yourself in that situation. After you picture yourself in the situation, click "Next" and then you'll see examples of thoughts, feelings, and behaviors that might happen in that situation. 

Some of the thoughts, feelings, and behaviors will be helpful and some won't be.

The goal of this exercise is to help you learn that there are lots of different reactions that you might have in a scary situation, and not all of these thoughts, feelings, and behaviors have to be negative. 

After you see some thoughts, you'll be asked to write your own example of a helpful thought that you might have in that situation. You'll do the same thing for feelings and behaviors.
Picture yourself in the situation on the next page.
You are outside on a cool day and see your friends down the street. You decide to jog over to say hi. When you get to your friends, you feel out of breath.

You are outside on a cool day and see your friends down the street. You decide to jog over to say hi. When you get to your friends, you feel out of breath.

Here are some thoughts that might pop into mind:

Text: It is a nice day for a jog.
That was a good jog.
I feel like I'm going to die.
I think I'm being judged by my friends for being out of breath, but they probably don't even notice.
The tightness in my chest is really uncomfortable, but I know it'll go away soon.

Parameters.Text:
Now's your chance to be creative! What could you say to yourself to make you feel better in this situation?  

For the next 30 seconds, write as many different thoughts that you might have that would be helpful in this situation. You can use the thoughts that you saw a moment ago for inspiration, or can list things that you've told yourself in the past that have helped.

Great job! Now you'll see some feelings.

You are outside on a cool day and see your friends down the street. You decide to jog over to say hi. When you get to your friends, you feel out of breath.

Here are some feelings that might happen in the moment:

Text: I'm feel happy to see my friends.
I feel invigorated.
I'm worried I'm really sick because of the tightness in my chest.
Even though I'm a little embarrassed that I'm out of breath when I see my friends, I know that they aren't judging me.
Feeling out of breath reminds me of how I feel when I'm a little anxious, which is interesting to notice.

Parameters.Text:
Now you try! What are some feelings that you could have in the moment? These don't have to only be feelings that you've had in the past or negative feelings that you assume you'd have in the moment. I'm worried that I've lost all of my friends, but the remind myself that's not realistic.

Great job! Now you'll see some behaviors.

You are looking through your social media app and see a number of your friends have posted to their stories. As you look through their photos, you realize that a few of your close friends were all hanging out without you. 

Here are some behaviors that someone might do at that moment or in the future:

Text: I post a nice comment on the picture.
I message my friend and let them know I would love to hang out with them next time.
I decide to block my friends' accounts.
I really want to ask my friends why I wasn't invited, but decide that I don't need to ask.
I want to cry, but remind myself that I've hung out with some of those friends without everyone there.

Parameters.Text:
You are looking through your social media app and see a number of your friends have posted to their stories. As you look through their photos, you realize that a few of your close friends were all hanging out without you. 

Behaviors you might do in the moment:
Excellent work! Now you'll do a Quick Thinking exercise and then you'll be done for today.

Next, you're going to see a scenario that might make you anxious. As you read the short story, picture yourself in that situation. After you picture yourself in the situation, click "Next" and then you'll see examples of thoughts, feelings, and behaviors that might happen in that situation. 

Some of the thoughts, feelings, and behaviors will be helpful and some won't be.

The goal of this exercise is to help you learn that there are lots of different reactions that you might have in a scary situation, and not all of these thoughts, feelings, and behaviors have to be negative. 

After you see some thoughts, you'll be asked to write your own example of a helpful thought that you might have in that situation. You'll do the same thing for feelings and behaviors.
Picture yourself in the situation on the next page.
You go to your grandparents' home for the first time in a while and notice that your grandfather looks a lot less healthy than you remember. No one in your family mentions it.

You go to your grandparents' home for the first time in a while and notice that your grandfather looks a lot less healthy than you remember. No one in your family mentions it. 

Here are some thoughts that might pop into mind:

Text: I wonder how my grandfather is feeling.
He's happy to see me.
My grandfather must be dying.
I think about how miserable I would be if he passes away, but then remind myself to enjoy my time with him today.
My family must be keeping a secret about his health, but then tell myself that everyone ages.

Text: I feel happy to see my grandfather.
I feel excited to catch him up on all the new things that are going on in my life.
I'm worried about how he looks.
I'm scared to lose him, but know that I can handle grief.
I feel anxious about his health, but tolerate the anxiety.

Great job! You've completed the first of three training exercises. Next you'll do the same exercise with a new story. 

Again, the goal of this exercise is to help you learn that there are lots of different reactions that you might have in a scary situation, and not all of these thoughts, feelings, and behaviors have to be negative.
Picture yourself in the situation on the next page.
As you're getting into the shower, you see a huge spider on the wall. You turn away for a second and look back and realize it's gone.

As you're getting into the shower, you see a huge spider on the wall. You turn away for a second and look back and realize it's gone. 

Here are some thoughts that might pop into mind:

Text: It's probably not coming back.
I think it was afraid of me.
It's probably on me!
I think about all of the places the spider could be, but decide it doesn't matter.
I think about how scary the spider looked, but realized how small it really was.

I feel freaked out, but know that I'm brave enough to take my shower anyway.

Way to go! Now you just have one training exercise left. You're going to practice coming up with thoughts, feelings, and behaviors one more time, and this time the story is going to be from a different topic than the first two you just did. This is to help your brain practice this kind of thinking in lots of different types of situations.
Picture yourself in the situation on the next page.
You have a lot of chores that you have to do tonight, and you also have a big project that's due tomorrow. Both have to get done, and you think about how you'll handle it all.

You have a lot of chores that you have to do tonight, and you also have a big project that's due tomorrow. Both have to get done, and you think about how you'll handle it all. 

Here are some thoughts that might pop into mind:

Text: I can manage both tasks.
I think this will help me organize thoughtfully in the future.
I don't think I can manage all of these tasks.
I hate feeling like I have so much to do, but I'll do my best to get it all done.
I think this is too much work, but decide to think positively about the outcome.

Here are some feelings that might happen in the moment:

Text: I'm excited to listen to my favorite artist while I do my chores.
I'm calm as I prioritize my chores and school work.
I'm anxious about being able to get everything done.
Although I feel overwhelmed, I try and feel grateful for being in school and for the home that I live in.
I feel upset about all I have to do, but I imagine how it will feel to have it all accomplished.

Parameters.Text:
You have a lot of chores that you have to do tonight, and you also have a big project that's due tomorrow. Both have to get done, and you think about how you'll handle it all. 

Behaviors you might do in the moment:
Excellent work! Now you'll do a Quick Thinking exercise and then you'll be done for today.

On the next screen, you'll see a situation that might make someone nervous, worried, scared, or anxious. Here's an example:

You're out with friends and receive this message from your parent saying, "You need to come home right now."

In the text box, please write as many different thoughts that might come to your mind in that moment. You can add each thought to a new line. You'll have 60 seconds to do this. 

For this example, you might write: 
What did I do wrong? 
 My parent has something really important to tell me. 
 I'm really tired, so I'm glad to be going home. 

The screen will automatically change after 60 seconds.

You don't need to write full sentences, and you should push yourself to write as many different thoughts as possible! These can be a mix of positive and negative thoughts. To add another thought, press the Submit button on your screen.

Imagine yourself in the following situation. Please write as many different thoughts that might come to mind in that moment. You have 60 seconds. You can press "enter" or "return" on your keyboard between thoughts. 

Your teacher is about to hand back graded tests from last week, and you remember how hard the test was.
Great job practicing flexible thinking today. Remember, try to use your new flexible thinking skills before your next training session!
